Diversification reduces unsystematic risk by investing across different assets or sectors.
Inflation is the general rise in prices that reduces the purchasing power of money.
Leverage means using borrowed funds to increase the potential return (and risk) of an investment.
Value at Risk (VaR) estimates the maximum expected loss over a time horizon at a given confidence level.
Expected Shortfall (CVaR) is the average loss given that the loss exceeds the VaR threshold.
Duration measures a bond’s price sensitivity to changes in interest rates.
Liquidity risk is the risk that an asset cannot be sold quickly without a significant price concession.
A call option gives the right, but not the obligation, to buy an asset at a specified strike price before or at expiry.
A forward contract obligates two parties to trade an asset at a set price on a future date.
Systematic risk affects the entire market and cannot be eliminated by diversification.
The Sharpe ratio measures risk-adjusted return by comparing excess return to volatility.
Beta measures a security’s sensitivity to movements of the overall market.
Finance is the study and management of money, investments, and financial systems.
